sources.data_found: Tufts University Fact Book 2023-2024: Provides enrollment data for School of Engineering and School of Arts & Sciences. CS is offered in both schools.
NSF Award #1925466 (MRI: Acquisition of a High Performance Computing Cluster...): Funded the acquisition of '16 GPU nodes' in late 2019 (likely V100 era).

student_data.notes: Undergraduate count derived from Tufts Fact Book 2023-2024 (Fall 2023 enrollment): Sum of Computer Science majors in School of Engineering (BS) and School of Arts & Sciences (BA/BS). Graduate count represents MS in Computer Science. PhD count represents PhD in Computer Science. Note: Does not include 'Data Science' or 'Computer Engineering' majors to maintain strict CS definition.

gpu_resources.notes:
Tufts IT documentation states the cluster has '60+ GPUs' consisting of V100 and A100 models. Breakdown estimated based on historical NSF awards and standard node configurations verified in user guides:
1) V100: 20 nodes × 2 GPUs/node = 40 V100s (Correlates with 2019 NSF MRI grant for 16 nodes + standard expansion).
2) A100: Remaining count to match '60+' total = ~20-24 GPUs. Estimated as 6 nodes × 4 A100s (PCie) = 24 A100s.
Total GPUs = 40 (V100) + 24 (A100) = 64, fitting the '60+' description. No H100s currently listed in public partition documentation. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

compute_credits.description: Tufts HPC is generally free for Tufts researchers; paid options exist for dedicated hardware but no specific 'credit' dollar amount is publicly listed.

analysis_notes: Tufts does not publish a live real-time dashboard of node specifications. GPU counts are derived from the official 'About Tufts HPC' statement of '60+ GPUs' and 'V100 and A100 cards', cross-referenced with NSF grant history to determine the likely split between generations.
